channel.title: Help a Noob out? Java
channel.description:
I know i'm posting quite a bit here, tell me to stop whenever, i'm just really interested in gaining all the knowledge i possibly can atm.
So, quick question. How do i set the users input from a scanner into a variable? for example... say i had scanner set up to the name 'scan', and i had a variable at the top saying... double funds; ... how would i set it so it's something along the lines of whatever the user inputs = funds ?.. incase i didn't explain that the best here's a quick example: [code] double funds; System.out.println("enter funds here: "+scan.nextLine()); scan.nextLine() == funds;[/code] ?? i know that's incorrect. I need help on making it correct? (Sorry if i haven't explained myself too well in this question) thanks all in advance.

item.title: Help a Noob out? Java
item.dc:creator: @austinsobes austinsobes
item.description:
@austinsobes wrote:

t4:

pretty sure all programming languages use = as assignment and == (or something else) as a equivalency comparator.

BASIC and Visual Basic have no comparison operators as == I believe. I know for sure Visual Basic is = for both assignment and comparison. However I’m not positive for BASIC.

Read full topic

item.title: Help a Noob out? Java
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:6, topic:435378”]pretty sure all programming languages use = as assignment and == (or something else) as a equivalency comparator.[/quote]all programming languages??? blind assumption… even on the imperative spectrum i think you’re forgetting the whole branch of ALGOL derived languages that use := as assignment (pascal, ada, etc.) and the languages that completely lack the idea of assignment ie. many concatenative languages like forth

[quote=“imsuperman05, post:8, topic:435378”][quote author=Fat Cookies link=topic=538097.msg3939474#msg3939474 date=1331304375]

pretty sure all programming languages use = as assignment and == (or something else) as a equivalency comparator.

Hurr: Integer;
Durr: Integer;

begin
    Hurr := 0;
    Durr := 1;

       if (Hurr = Durr) then
          Writeln("No hurr durr");
end.

[/quote]

that looks like a scripting language… syntax looks pretty user-friendly. What’s Pascal used for these days?[/quote]lots of things, although it’s not as widely used as it used to be however i’ve personally seen things ranging from tidal analysis tools to x86-64 kernels. there’s also a lot of legacy applications written in pascal, and it’s often used in academics as it’s easy to understand and learn.

Read full topic

item.title: Help a Noob out? Java
item.dc:creator: @imsuperman05 imsuperman05
item.description:
@imsuperman05 wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:7, topic:435378”][quote author=t4 link=topic=538097.msg3938944#msg3938944 date=1331259020]
pretty sure all programming languages use = as assignment and == (or something else) as a equivalency comparator.
[/quote]

[code=pascal]
Hurr: Integer;
Durr: Integer;

begin
Hurr := 0;
Durr := 1;

   if (Hurr = Durr) then
      Writeln("No hurr durr");

end.
[/code][/quote]

that looks like a scripting language… syntax looks pretty user-friendly. What’s Pascal used for these days?

Read full topic

item.title: Help a Noob out? Java
item.dc:creator: @austinsobes austinsobes
item.description:
@austinsobes wrote:

I’d like to add to ollie123’s post. In these mid-level programming languages. Almost 80+% use = as an Assignment operator, and == as a comparison operator. That being said, When programming always write as you talk.

scan.nextLine() = funds;
scan dot next line(input) is now equal to funds;

That’s not what you want is it?

funds = scan.nextLine();
funds is now equal to scan dot next line(input)

Basically, you want it to be be said in your head as, “Variable Funds is going to be set as User Input”.

Programming almost always works as a ‘this’ to ‘that’. Everything on the left is being assigned or compared to what is on the right. Also, check your MSN. I sent you a book on Java programming which will greatly help your programming skills. I used the same company to learn C#. Learn almost all of the syntax within a week up until networking. Good luck!

Read full topic

item.title: Help a Noob out? Java
item.dc:creator: @ollie123 Ollie123
item.description:
@ollie123 wrote:

[quote=“V1, post:1, topic:435378”]I know i’m posting quite a bit here, tell me to stop whenever, i’m just really interested in gaining all the knowledge i possibly can atm.

So, quick question. How do i set the users input from a scanner into a variable? for example… say i had scanner set up to the name ‘scan’, and i had a variable at the top saying… double funds; … how would i set it so it’s something along the lines of whatever the user inputs = funds ?.. incase i didn’t explain that the best here’s a quick example: double funds; System.out.println("enter funds here: "+scan.nextLine()); scan.nextLine() == funds; ?? i know that’s incorrect. I need help on making it correct?
(Sorry if i haven’t explained myself too well in this question)
thanks all in advance.[/quote]

double funds;
System.out.print("enter funds here:");
funds = Double.parseDouble(scan.nextLine());

Remember: = is assignment, == is comparison

Read full topic
